questions.question: John had \(\frac{5}{8}\) of a pizza. He ate \(\frac{1}{4}\) of what he had. What fraction of the whole pizza did he eat?
Express \(\frac{7}{12}\) as a fraction with denominator 36
A rope 24m long was cut into 3 pieces. The first piece was \(\frac{3}{8}\) of the rope, the second was \(\frac{1}{3}\) of the rope. What fraction of the rope was the third piece?
questions.explanation:
First: \(\frac{3}{8} = \frac{9}{24}\), Second: \(\frac{1}{3} = \frac{8}{24}\)
Total of first two: \(\frac{9}{24} + \frac{8}{24} = \frac{17}{24}\)
Third piece: \(1 - \frac{17}{24} = \frac{7}{24}\)

questions.question: Mr. Tan gave \(\frac{1}{4}\) of his stamps to Ali and \(\frac{2}{5}\) of the remainder to Bob. What fraction of his original stamps did he have left?
questions.explanation:
Let total stamps = 1
To Ali: \(\frac{1}{4}\), Remainder: \(1 - \frac{1}{4} = \frac{3}{4}\)
To Bob: \(\frac{2}{5} \times \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6}{20} = \frac{3}{10}\)
Total given: \(\frac{1}{4} + \frac{3}{10} = \frac{5}{20} + \frac{6}{20} = \frac{11}{20}\)
Left: \(1 - \frac{11}{20} = \frac{9}{20}\)

questions.question: In a class, \(\frac{3}{7}\) of the students are boys. If there are 6 more girls than boys, how many students are in the class?
questions.explanation:
Boys = \(\frac{3}{7}\), Girls = \(\frac{4}{7}\)
Difference: \(\frac{4}{7} - \frac{3}{7} = \frac{1}{7}\)
If \(\frac{1}{7}\) of total = 6 students
Then total students = \(6 \times 7 = 42\)
